Danays Kunka

  • Endereço para acessar este CV: http://lattes.cnpq.br/5072717844597734
  • Última atualização do currículo em 13/02/2018

Danays Kunka is a member of the X-ray Optics Group at the division of Optics and Photonics at the Institute of Microstructure Technology (IMT) of the Karlsruhe Institute of Technology (KIT) since September 2011. She is currently responsible for the X-ray Imaging Application Group at the IMT and Mentor at the Karlsruhe School of Optics and Photonics (KSOP) of the KIT. Danays Kunka is responsible from the German side for the s-BrAXIN the South Brazilian/German Research Network for developing new technologies in X-Ray Imaging. She obtained her Ph.D. in Physics at the Catholic University of Rio de Janeiro (PUC-Rio) in 2001, where she worked as a scientist until 2006. She also worked at the Institute of Experimental Nuclear Physics of the KIT from 2006 until 2011. She holds a degree in Physics with a master-of-science-equivalent title from the State University of Belarus (BGU), Republic of Belarus and the Higher Institute of Nuclear Science and Technology (ISCTN), Cuba (1987-1993) and a Ph.D. in Physics from the Pontifical Catholic University of Rio de Janeiro (2001). She has experience in experimental Physics, with a current emphasis on X-Ray imaging techniques for biophysics, chemistry, and materials science applications. (Texto informado pelo autor)

Linhas de pesquisa
1.
Research activities for optoelectronic and Metrology applied to experimental astroparticle physics for the ?Pierre Auger Observatory?
Objetivo: - Absolute calibration of the German fluorescence yield experiment AirLight and activities related to a similar experiment at international level, AirFly; - Data analysis of the absolute calibration of a fluorescence yield experiments AirLight and AirFly.
Palavras-chave: Fluorescence Yield Experiments: AirLight, AirFly; Projeto Pierre Auger; Experimental Astroparticle Physics.
2.
Development and characterization of optical components for X-ray Phase Sensitive Imaging
Objetivo: Emerging X-ray optics, which aims to develop novel optical elements for multi-modal information acquisition based on small angle scattering, absorption and phase contrast. With these elements the development of new X-ray imaging modalities for biomedical and material science applications at synchrotron facilities and at X-ray laboratories are supported.
Palavras-chave: Emerging X-ray optics; Deep X-ray Lithography.
3.
Sensor development at Physics and Mechanic Engineering Departments: materials modification during poling of special fibers based on novel glasses for applications in optical sensors devices, development of fiber Brag grating sensors for the oil industry.
